verses.verse: And the Separatists and some of the Old Testament transcribers who came out of Greater Jerusalem were gathered together to Him.
And when they saw some of His students eating loaves of bread with shared hands, that is with unwashed hands, they found fault.
You see, the Separatists and all the Jewish people do not eat unless they wash the hands with a fist, holding on to the tradition of the older men.

And after coming from the marketplace, they do not eat unless they submerge themselves, and there are many other regulations that they took in to be holding on to: submersions of cups, pots, copper items, and cots.

Following that, the Separatists and the Old Testament transcribers ask Him, "Why do Your students not traipse around in line with the tradition of the older men, but eat the bread with unwashed hands?"

When Jesus answered, He said to them, "Isaiah nicely preached about you, the fakers, as it has been written, (in Isaiah 29:13) 'This ethnic group values Me with the lips, but their heart has itself far away from Me.
They worship Me in a futile way, teaching instructions that are people's regulations.'
You see, after leaving the demand of God, you hold on to the tradition of the people, submersion of pots and cups. And you are doing many other things resembling these types of things."
And He was saying to them, "You nicely invalidate the demand of God so that you might keep your tradition.
You see, Moses said, (in Exodus 20:12) 'Value your father and your mother,' and, (in Exodus 21:17) 'The person who says bad things about a father or mother must pass away with death.'
But you say if a person says to the father or the mother, 'It is a Corban (that is Hebrew for a contribution), whatever should have benefited you from me,'
you even leave him to no longer do anything for his father or his mother,
terminating the message of God with your tradition that you gave out. And you are doing many things resembling these types of things."
And after He called for all the crowd, He was saying to them, "Listen to Me everyone, and understand.
There is nothing outside of the person, traveling into him, that is able to make him shared, but the things traveling out from him, these are the things that make the person shared.
If someone has ears to be listening, he must listen."
And when He went into a house away from the crowd, his students were asking Him about the illustration.
And He says to them, "Are you also clueless like this? Aren't you aware that everything on the outside traveling into the person is not able to make him shared
because it is not traveling into his heart, but into the belly? And it travels out into the sewer, cleaning all the food."
He was saying, "The thing traveling out of the person, that thing makes the person shared.
You see, the considerations, the bad ones, travel out from the inside, from the heart of the people. Cheatings on a spouse, sexual sins, murders,
thefts, desires for more, evils, deception, indulgent activity, an evil eye, a hurtful comment, pride, distraction:
all these evil things travel out from the inside and make the person shared."
And when He got up from there, He went off into the adjoining borders of Tyre and Sidon. And when He went into the house, He was not wanting anyone to know. And He was not able to be unnoticed.
You see, after a woman heard about Him (whose little daughter of hers had a spirit that was not clean), when she came, she got down close to His feet.
The woman was Greek, a Syrian-Phoenician by birth. And she was asking Him that He would throw the demon out of her daughter.
But Jesus said to her, "First, leave the children to be full. You see, it is not nice to take the bread of the children and throw it to the little dogs."
But the woman answered and says to Him, "Yes, Master, you see, even the little dogs beneath the table eat from the crumbs of the young children."
And He said to her, "Because of this answer, go back; the demon has come out of your daughter."
And when she went off to her house, she found that the demon had come out and that the daughter had been thrown on the cot.
And again when He came out from the borders of Tyre and Sidon, He went to the Sea of Galilee up in the middle of the borders of Decapolis.
And they bring to Him a hearing-impaired tongue-tied man and encourage Him that He might place His hand on him.
And after He took him off away from the crowd by Himself, He put his fingers into his ears, and after He spit, He touched his tongue.
And when He looked up into the sky, He groaned and says to him, "Ephphatha," that is Aramaic for, "Open completely."
And right away the hearing of his ears was completely opened, the restraint of his tongue was released, and he was speaking correctly.
And He warned them that they should tell it to no one, but as much as He was warning them, instead they were speaking publicly much more.
And they were being impressed even much more, saying, "He has done everything nicely. He makes both the hearing-impaired people to be hearing, and the mute to be speaking."
